content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Taiwan's substantial achievements in health include high life expectancy and low maternal and infant mortality rates, making it important for international health cooperation. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy and low maternal and infant mortality rates, comparable to western countries. They have also eradicated infectious diseases like cholera, smallpox, the plague, and polio, and provided hepatitis B vaccinations to children. Taiwan collaborates closely with the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on public health issues and has shown willingness to assist in international health activities. In response to an earthquake in El Salvador, Taiwan sent rescue teams with specialists in firefighting, medicine, and civil engineering. In response to a 7.6 and 7.9 magnitude earthquake in El Salvador, Taiwan sent 2 rescue teams with 90 specialists in firefighting, medicine, and civil engineering. The Taiwanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs also donated $200,000 in relief aid to El Salvador. The United States declared its support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO). Taiwan's participation in the WHO can bring significant health benefits to the country. Taiwan seeks participation in WHO with support from US President Bush and Secretary of Health Thompson. They aim for meaningful involvement despite membership limitations. In May 2002, Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced US support for Taiwan's efforts to gain observership status at the World Health Assembly. Taiwan donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS in 2002. In 2003, Taiwan experienced 84 deaths due to the SARS outbreak. Avian influenza has reemerged in Asia. The SARS outbreak caused 84 deaths in Taiwan. Avian influenza has reemerged in Asia, with strains reported in various countries. The outbreaks highlight the importance of global cooperation in health organizations like the WHO. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse Taiwan for observer status at international health summits. The Secretary of State is authorized to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly summit in Geneva, Switzerland. A report must be submitted to Congress annually detailing the plan for Taiwan's observer status.
